definition.p: A set is an unordered collection of objects called elements or members of the set.
If A is a set and a is an element of A, we write a \in A. If b isn't an element of A, we write b \not\in A.

Here are some special sets we will visit often throughout the course and the rest of your mathematical career:
\emptyset = \{\} is the empty set consisting of no elements.
\mathbb{N} = \{0, 1, 2, 3, 4, \dots \} is the set of natural numbers.
\mathbb{Z} = \{\dots, -3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3, \dots \} is the set of integers.
\mathbb{Z}^+ = \{1, 2, 3, \dots \} is the set of positive integers.
\mathbb{Q} = \left\{ \frac{p}{q} \mid p \in \mathbb{Z}, q \in \mathbb{Z}, \text{ and } q \not= 0 \right\} is the set of rational numbers.
\mathbb{R} is the set of real numbers. In Calculus, we wrote the interval (-\infty, \infty).
\mathbb{R}^+ is the set of positive real numbers. In Calculus, we wrote the interval (0, \infty)
\mathbb{C} = \{a + bi \mid a \in \mathbb{R}, b \in \mathbb{R}, i = \sqrt{-1} \} is the set of complex numbers

We say that A is a subset of B, and write A \subseteq B if every element of A is an element of B.
If there is an element of B which is not also in A, we say that A is a proper subset of B and write A \subset B.
We say that two sets, A and B are equal, an write A = B they have exactly the same elements. A = B \iff (A \subseteq B \text{ and } B \subseteq A)

statement.p:
For every set S,
\emptyset \subseteq S and
S \subseteq S.

definition.p: Given any set S, the power set of S is the set of all subsets of the set S. We denote the power set of S by \pow(S)

statement.p: Find the power set of:

definition.p: Let S be a set. If there are exactly n distinct elements in S where n is a nonnegative integer, then we say that S is a finite set with cardinality of n, and write |S|=n.
A set is said to be infinite if it is not finite.

statement.p: Find the cardinality:

definition.p: We define an ordered n-tuple to be an ordered collection of the form (a_1, a_2, \dots, a_n).
We call the 2-tuple (a_1, a_2) an ordered pair, and the 3-tuple (a_1, a_2, a_3) an ordered triple.

Let A and B be sets. The Cartesian Product of A and B, denoted by A\times B, is the set of all ordered pairs (a,b) where a\in A and b \in B. That is, A \times B = \{ (a,b) \mid a\in A \text{ and } b \in B\}
We also denote the Cartesian product of a set with itself by the superscript A^2 = A \times A.

statement.p: Let A=\{1, 2\} and B = \{x, y , z\}, find:

ol.li: How many elements do you expect in A \times B?

definition.p: If A and B are two sets, we define the union of A and B, denoted A \cup B, to be the set of all elements that are in A or B, or both. A \cup B = \{ x \mid x \in A \text{ or } x \in B\}
If A and B are two sets, we define the intersection of A and B, denoted A \cap B, to be the set of only elements that are in both A and B. A \cap B = \{ x \mid x \in A \text{ and } x \in B\}

If A and B are two sets, we define the difference of A and B, denoted A \setminus B, to be the set of only elements that are only in A and not in B. A \setminus B = \{ x \mid x \in A \text{ and } x \not\in B\}

statement.p: It's worth noting that some authors, Rosen included, use A - B to denote the difference between two sets A and B. We'll be using the slightly more standard A\setminus B in this class.
Let A=\{a,b,c,d,e\} and B=\{a, b,c,d,e,f,g,h\}, find
What do you observe about some combination of the cardinalities above?
Verify the following identities by using a Venn Diagram.

note.p: The following is a listing of common identities for set operations. An identity is a statement which is true if we replace the variables with specific sets.

statement.p: Confirm for yourself that these identities are true by shading a Venn diagram for each side of the equalities.

Let A = \{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6\}, B = \{2, 4, 6\}, C = \{1, 2, 3\} and D = \{7, 8, 9\}. Determine which of the following are true, false, or meaningless.
A \subset B.
B \subset A.
B \in C.
\emptyset \in A.
\emptyset \subset A.
A \lt D.
3 \in C.
3 \subset C.
\{3\} \subset C.

li.p: False. For example, 1\in A but 1 \notin B.
True. Every element in B is an element in A.
False. The elements in C are 1, 2, and 3. The set B is not equal to 1, 2, or 3.
False. A has exactly 6 elements, and none of them are the empty set.
True. Everything in the empty set (nothing) is also an element of A. Notice that the empty set is a subset of every set.
Meaningless. A set cannot be less than another set.
True. 3 is one of the elements of the set C.
Meaningless. 3 is not a set, so it cannot be a subset of another set.
True. 3 is the only element of the set \{3\}, and is an element of C, so every element in \{3\} is an element of C.

statement.p:
Let A = \{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6\}, B = \{2, 4, 6\}, C = \{1, 2, 3\} and D = \{7, 8, 9\}. If the universe is U = \{1, 2, \ldots, 10\}, find:
A \cup B.
A \cap B.
B \cap C.
A \cap D.
\bar{B \cup C}.
A \setminus B.
(D \cap \bar C) \cup \bar{A \cap B}.
\emptyset \cup C.
\emptyset \cap C.

ol.li: A \cup B = \{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6\} = A since everything in B is already in A.
A \cap B = \{2, 4, 6\} = B since everything in B is in A.
B \cap C = \{2\} as the only element of both B and C is 2.
A \cap D = \emptyset since A and D have no common elements.
\bar{B \cup C} = \{5, 7, 8, 9, 10\}. First we find that B \cup C = \{1, 2, 3, 4, 6\}, then we take everything not in that set.
A \setminus B = \{1, 3, 5\} since the elements 1, 3, and 5 are in A but not in B. This is the same as A \cap \bar B.
(D \cap \bar C) \cup \bar{A \cap B} = \{1, 3, 5, 7, 8, 9, 10\}. The set contains all elements that are either in D but not in C (i.e., \{7,8,9\}), or not in both A and B (i.e., \{1,3,5,7,8,9,10\}).
\emptyset \cup C = C since nothing is added by the empty set.
\emptyset \cap C = \emptyset since nothing can be both in a set and in the empty set.

statement.p:
Let A = \{1,2,3,4,5\}, B = \{3,4,5,6,7\}, and C = \{2,3,5\}.
Find A \cap B.
Find A \cup B.
Find A \setminus B.
Find A \cap \overline{(B \cup C)}.
Find A \times C.
Is C \subseteq A? Explain.
Is C \subseteq B? Explain.

li.p: Yes. All three elements of C are also elements of A.
No. There is an element of C, namely the element 2, which is not an element of B.

statement.p:
Let A = \{x \in \N \st 3 \le x \le 13\}, B = \{x \in \N \st x \mbox{ is even} \}, and {C = \{x \in \N \st x \mbox{ is odd} \}}.
Find A \cap B.
Find A \cup B.
Find B \cap C.
Find B \cup C.
Find an example of sets A and B such that A\cap B = \{3, 5\} and A \cup B = \{2, 3, 5, 7, 8\}.

solution.p: There are many possible examples. Here is a simple one. Let A=\{3, 5\} and B=\{2, 3, 5, 7, 8\}

statement.p: Find an example of sets A and B such that A \subseteq B and A \in B.

Draw a Venn diagram to represent each of the following:
A \cup \bar B
\bar{(A \cup B)}
A \cap (B \cup C)
(A \cap B) \cup C
\bar A \cap B \cap \bar C
(A \cup B) \setminus C

image.description: Venn diagram of \bar A \cap B \cap \bar C

statement.p: Describe a set in terms of A and B (using set notation) which has the following Venn diagram:

image.description: Venn diagram: A is mostly shaded, B is mostly shaded, but the area where A and B overlap is not.

solution.p: One way to answer is (A\cup B) \setminus (A\cap B)

statement.p: Let A = \{a, b, c, d\}. Find \pow(A).

hint.p: We are looking for a set containing 16 sets.

statement.p: Let A = \{1,2,3,4,5,6\}. Find all sets B \in \pow(A) which have the property \{2,3,5\} \subseteq B.
Find an example of sets A and B such that |A| = 4, |B| = 5, and |A \cup B| = 9.
Let A = \{1,2,\ldots, 10\}. How many subsets of A contain exactly one element (i.e., how many singleton subsets are there)? How many doubleton subsets (containing exactly two elements) are there?

solution.p: There are 10 subsets that consist of a single element. For subsets consisting of exactly two elements, there are 90

statement.p: Find an example of sets A and B such that |A| = 3, |B| = 4, and |A \cup B| = 5.

solution.p: There are many examples. Here's one possibility: A = \{ a, b, c\}, B=\{b,c,d,e\}. Then the union is A \cup B = \{a, b, c, d, e\}.

statement.p: Are there sets A and B such that |A| = |B|, |A\cup B| = 10, and |A\cap B| = 5? Explain.

solution.p: The answer is no. Can you explain why?

statement.p: In a regular deck of playing cards there are 26 red cards and 12 face cards. Explain, using sets and what you have learned about cardinalities, why there are only 32 cards which are either red or a face card.

solution.p: The intersection of the set of red cards and the set of face cards is nonempty. It includes six cards: Jack of Hearts, Queen of Hearts, King of Hearts, Jack of Diamonds, Queen of Diamonds, and King of Diamonds.

statement.p:
Recall \Z = \{\ldots,-2,-1,0, 1,2,\ldots\} (the integers). Let \Z^+ = \{1, 2, 3, \ldots\} be the positive integers. Let 2\Z be the even integers, 3\Z be the multiples of 3, and so on.
Is \Z^+ \subseteq 2\Z? Explain.
Is 2\Z \subseteq \Z^+? Explain.
Find 2\Z \cap 3\Z. Describe the set in words, and using set notation.

ol.li: 2\Z \cap 3\Z is the set of all integers which are multiples of both 2 and 3 (so multiples of 6). Therefore 2\Z \cap 3\Z = \{x \in \Z \st \exists y\in \Z(x = 6y)\}.
